page.title: 15GAMEKEEPING AT BLACKDOWN
page.content: At Blackdown there is a keeper called Sidney Fidler. He keeps three pens full of pheasants. The pens are sited in the shade of trees. He keeps the pheasants' feed in a big tin drum so that rats and mice cannot eat it. He puts water in plastic drums which he has sawn in half. He feeds the birds every morning and every evening. The young birds which are delivered to him to rear are called poults. They eat chick crumbs at first and then, when they are older, they eat barley, corn, wheat and other crops. When the pheasants are fully grown they are let out of the pen; if not they just fly over the fence! The adult males will mate with about six females and produce more chicks. Pheasants are shot for sport and for consumption.
